THE CONTEST.
In THE NEWS-LETTER Of October 28 the
editors offered two prizes of $io each—one for
the best collection of verses not exceeding
thirty lines, and the other for the best short
story of not less than moo,nor more than 2000,
words. This was done to encourage real, honest efforts to make good literature, for there is
no reason why Hopkins men cannot write
verses and stories, if they only take enough
interest in their own literary development and
In giving to others about them their very best
thoughts. Everyone—a student especially—
needs to train himself in the art of translating
thoughts into words. One may argue that
he can think of nothing to write. But all of us
have at divers and sundry times amorphous
imaginings and incoherent thoughts which
would take a definite shape, so that we ourselves, and perhaps others, too, might profit by
them,if we did but undertake earnestly the task
of putting them in words. We come to Hopkins to be trained to think ; we should take
care while here not to neglect to train ourselves to express our thoughts. College training is too apt, we fear, to produce "critics,"
but what we need is men of action. Youth is
the time of action. We hope, then, that the
publication of the successful poems will not be
the end of literary efforts among the student
body, but that others may still continue their
efforts, though, perhaps, they did not gain the
prize in the present case.
Since two of the poems have been deemed
worthy of prizes by the committee, the $10 offered will be divided equally between the two
successful competitors, whose names are
Roger Griswold Perkins (norn de plume, Oliver
Wolcott); poem, "Voices of the Woods;" and
Carol Wight (nom de plume, Petrarch), poem,
"Farewell."
Mr. Perkins is a senior at the Medical School
and was graduated with the degree of A. B.

No. 6

from Union College in 1893, and also from
Harvard in 1894. He is from Schenectady,
New York.
Mr. Wight is a member of the class of 19oo.
He is also from New York State, his home being in Brooklyn.
The report of the committee of judges which
follows explains itself:
JOHNS HOPKINS urrivieiterrv.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18, 1897.
Editors of News-Letter:
GENTLEMEN—We,your committee to judge
upon stories and poems submitted in competition for prizes offered by NEWS-LETTER, report:
1. No story submitted is deemed worthy of
prize offered.
2. The prize for poetical work is awarded to
the authors of "Voices of the Woods,"
and "Farewell." The prize is to be divided equally.
All of which is respectfully submitted.
H. B. ADAMS (Chairman),
HERBERT E. GREENE,
GUY CARLETON LEE.

VOICES OF THE WOODS.

As I wander to and fro,
Through the wood-paths, in and out,
In the air I seem to hear
Fairy voices round about—
Singing praises far and near
To Elizabeth.
All the flowers seem to say :
"Blest are we that we may lie
On her bosom, near her heart—
What care we that we must die,
So our lives some joy impart
To Elizabeth ?"

THE NEWS -LETTER.

Birds are singing in the trees,
As the branches swing and sway :
"Happy we that we can flee,
Whether near or far away,
To her presence, just to see
Fair Elizabeth.
Ah! ye lucky birds and flowers!
Would that I could take your place—
Could her meditations hear;
See the lights upon her face
When she thinks that no one's near.
Ah!Elizabeth.
Dost thou ever think of one
Who would always happy be
To fulfill thy lightest thought—
Dost thou ever think of me?
Love like mine cannot be bought,
Dear Elizabeth.

Ah,vanishing vision! and wilt thou cast
One smile on the heart whose heaven ends
When thou and beauty have southward past
To light the life of some happier friends?
When the ivory brow of morning glow
With crimson fire and the planets pale;
When the wind-wooed branches murmur low
Or roar as they wrest with the riing gale;
Iv.
When her icy kiss the darkness seal
On the rose-leaf lips of the dying day;
When the purple splendor of twilight steal
The heart from self and the world away;
Then, Oh!then, think, if thou wilt, that he,
Who well might mourn that we ever met,
Must dream on a love that can never be
Fulfilled, or else, if thou wilt, forget!

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
PROF. SHERWOOD ON "BERLIN."

Professor Sherwood delivered an address
before the Historical and Political Science Association on Friday evening. "Berlin" was
the subject he discussed, and his talk was based
Upon reminiscences of a short stop in that city
last summer. Professor Sherwood expressed
his disappointment with the famous boulevard,
Unter den Linden. It is true, the street is
about two hundred feet wide, and has its sides
adorned with rows of horse-chestnut trees and
lindens, though the latter are of rather a languishing nature.
In spite of several old ruins and crumbling
castles of historic interest, Berlin impresses
one as being a modern city. The houses are
built of brick and stone, and are almost entirely of a modern origin. The municipal government of Berlin is the pride of its inhabitants, and with much justice,for it is one of the
best governed cities in the world. In fact, the
officials seem to carry their measures for cleanliness, etc., almost to an extreme. During the
six weeks in which Professor Sherwood stayed
in the city it rained nearly every day; still the
galas between were busily occupied by the
water sprinklers.
One of the most serious problems which

3

confront the young men of the city is how to
make their moustaches grow in a way they
"hadn't orter." Hours are spent by the young
gallants of the city in barber shops, where tedious efforts are made to force the ends of the
moustaches to take that much-desired upward
movement. Although Berlin is one of the
largest cities in Europe, yet it does not give
one the impression of being a metropolis; especially is this fact brought out by the nature of
the newspapers, which are distinctly provincial
in character. Berlin is a great business centre,
but appearances are deceptive. Almost the
only signs of vigorous activity in the business
world are shown by the cabmen, who seem to
be possessed of a mania to run down and ride
over everything in sight. Professor Sherwood
found that it was not worth one's life to criticise the Emperor, though a considerable
amount of caution was usually employed in exercising that right.
The universities of Berlin have long been
famous, and students from all lands may be
found within their halls.
CAPITAL PUNISHI1ENT.

Statistics and Bible quotations were the favorite weapons of the speakers on the question
whether capital punishment should be abolished, which was discussed in the last session of
the Senate. The affirmative side won the debate. Those who took part, for the affirmative,
were Senators Dohme, Hubner and Hodges.
Those on the negative side were Senators Robinson, F. Smith and Brent. Senators Ballard
and Pender, who took part in the open debate,
showed that both these methods of argument
can be used to prove either yea or nay, and
that with them but little can be accomplished.
A short, humane plea, put forth by Senator
R. D. Miller, turned the tables against the adherents of rapid methods. The whole house
showed great interest in the progress and result of the debate.
The Senate will meet again on January 12,
1898, when Senators Gordon, Francis and Peters will speak for the annexation of Hawaii.
Senators M. Smith, Clunet and J. H. Palmer
will take the negative.

is different. Since the authorities have provided proper accommodations, they may reasonably require students to use them.
It is to be hoped that they will make physical
culture, in its place, just as important as laboratory work. The man of whom it is required
should be made to feel that the requirement
means something; that his attendance will be
marked and his absence noted. We question
whether the compulsion might not well be extended to all undergraduates instead of freshmen alone, as heretofore. We should grumble
somewhat, no doubt, as we do now at some
other things, but at the end of the course we
should be grateful. The College Congress bids
fair to be successful, where other plans failed,
because it has been made a part of the course
and attendance is required. The same may be
found true of gymnasium classes. For the
busy student regular exercise is a matter in
which the spirit is willing, but the flesh is often
very weak.

PHYSICAL TRAININO,

The new gymnasium and cage are almost
completed, and in a short time presumably
they will be thrown open to the students. This
should give a new impulse to all branches of
athletics. Candidates for the teams will devote themselves to practice. Many will moralize about the value of systematic exercise, and
will begin to use the apparatus diligently. The
novelty will speedily wear off, the work will
become irksome and they will give it up. Interest will fail, and we may find ourselves, with
a new gymnasium and the largest cage in the
country in just the same position in regard to
athletics as before. We are confident, however,that this will not be so, for we believe that
the businesslike management that marks the
University in other departments will prevail
likewise in the gymnasium. Last year physical culture, as a part of the course, existed
chiefly on the class books. Those of us who
remember our frequent dashes in scanty apparel between the barnlike gymnasium and inadequate bathroom on the ground floor, and
our lockers close under the roof of an adjoin-

HAZING AT W. C. B.

We learn from reliable sources that the
sophomores of the Woman's College have actually been reprimanded for hazing the freshmen. It must be explained, however, that it is
not the rough-and-tumble, pot-social variety
with which we are familiar. At one time, we
are told, they presented the freshmen with
sticks of candy tied with green ribbons. Again
they mingled the bray of horns with the sweet
strains of freshmen concerts, and cut the jaunty
tassels from freshmen caps. We are surprised
and pained. After the Dean has persuaded
us to give up matriculation hazing, and the
freshmen and juniors have lived in peace for
three months, it is "perfectly awful" for them
to set us such an example.

PRACTICAL ECONOMICS.

A professor in economics at the Hopkins
has aroused the admiration of the department
by his complete mastery of his subject. He
rode a wheel through Europe last summer,and
at the end of his trip sold it for more than he
paid for it. The professor is to be congratulated for his clever application of economic
theory to fact.

number of critical works on Old Testament literature and has paid special attention to the
Book of Psalms. He will lecture in McCoy
Hall, alternating with Mr. Burton, on ''Phases
of Jewish Religious Life After the Exile."
THE GLEE CLUB.

The Glee Club has been chosen, subject to
change, by Mr. P. S. Evans of the Medical
School, a graduate of Yale, who led the Club so
successfully last year. This year the personnel
is: First tenor—W. W. Francis, F. J. Clunet,
H. A. Fowler, C. P. Rogers, E. H. Hume. Second tenor—S. P. Harwood, H. M. Reese, C. S.
Hodges, J. P. Hill, G. C. Robinson. First
bass—W. P. Stewart, E. A. Robinson, Jr., L.
M. Warfield, J. G. Peters. Second bass—J. F.
Young, F. W. Smith, J. E Ewell, K. Jungbluth.
These men are to train, and only those
deemed proficient after training will be members of the Club.

LECTURES IN JANUARY.

Of the two gentlemen who will lecture early
in January, Mr. Richard Burton, the Donovan
lecturer, is interesting as a former student of
the University. He received his A. B. degree
from Trinity College, Connecticut, in 1883,
and was made a doctor of philosophy by Hopkins in 1888. In 1887 he won a literary prize of
$100. From here he went to his home (Hartford, Conn.)and became an editor of The Hartford Courant, one of the prominent newspapers
of the country.
Mr. Burton has the somewhat unusual distinction of being known as a poet and a newspaper man. He read an original poem at the
first commencement held in McCoy Hall, in
June, 1894. In a list of representative alumni
the '97 Hullabaloo contains a picture of Mr.
Burton with the subjects of his theses. He will
deliver six lectures in McCoy Hall on "The
Modern Novel."
Rev. Thomas Kelly Cheyne, D. D., has a
wide reputation as a professor at Oxford and

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Mr. J. B. McCallum of the second-year class
met with a painful accident on Sunday, December 5, which, however, luckily did not result seriously. While walking down the street
two dogs that were tied together ran up to him,
one on each side. They tripped him up, and
his head struck on the sidewalk, lacerating his
scalp and knocking him senseless for some little time. As a result he was laid up for a number of days.
Dr. S. F. Baker was confined to his apartments last week with a cold and an attack of
tonsilitis. Dr. C. F. Barden had charge of his
class during his absence.
Professor Brooks' lectures proved very attractive to the medical students and the faculty
of the Medical School, many of them having
attended all the lectures, and a still larger number most of them.
WANTED—In Dr. Mall's department someone who has finished a "lower."

ATHLETICS.
HOCKEY.

The affairs of the Hockey League have been
settled and the opposition to the Maryland
Hockey Club has won its point debarring that
team from the League and getting ten per cent.
of the gate receipts at all games. The 'Varsity team played its first game on last Tuesday
night week, and lost to Northampton by 4
goals to 2. Scholl did not play at goal, and his
work in the field was not comparable with his
unexcelled goal tending. The 'Varsity was
outplayed in team work, the Northampton
men putting up a rattling, strong game.
Indoor baseball will begin as soon as the
cage is completed. The different classes have
been requested to organize teams to compete
for a prize, which will be presented to the
winning team. The prize is to be a handsome
banner, on which will appear the names of the
victorious players. The schedule of games will
be arranged later on.
On Monday some of the gymnasium apparatus was put in place. Several additions have
been made, among which are a double rowing
machine and striking- bag drum. A very fine
wrestling carpet has also been procured. This
carpet has long been needed. It is probable
that Professor Doyle will give lessons in
wrestling two afternoons a week.
The floor of the cage will be leveled and
rolled during the Christmas recess, and the
foundation for the running track will be laid.
The track will have to be banked somewhat
at the corners of the cage.

THE CONTEST.
In THE NEWS-LETTER Of October 28 the
editors offered two prizes of $io each—one for
the best collection of verses not exceeding
thirty lines, and the other for the best short
story of not less than moo,nor more than 2000,
words. This was done to encourage real, honest efforts to make good literature, for there is
no reason why Hopkins men cannot write
verses and stories, if they only take enough
interest in their own literary development and
In giving to others about them their very best
thoughts. Everyone—a student especially—
needs to train himself in the art of translating
thoughts into words. One may argue that
he can think of nothing to write. But all of us
have at divers and sundry times amorphous
imaginings and incoherent thoughts which
would take a definite shape, so that we ourselves, and perhaps others, too, might profit by
them,if we did but undertake earnestly the task
of putting them in words. We come to Hopkins to be trained to think ; we should take
care while here not to neglect to train ourselves to express our thoughts. College training is too apt, we fear, to produce "critics,"
but what we need is men of action. Youth is
the time of action. We hope, then, that the
publication of the successful poems will not be
the end of literary efforts among the student
body, but that others may still continue their
efforts, though, perhaps, they did not gain the
prize in the present case.
Since two of the poems have been deemed
worthy of prizes by the committee, the $10 offered will be divided equally between the two
successful competitors, whose names are
Roger Griswold Perkins (norn de plume, Oliver
Wolcott); poem, "Voices of the Woods;" and
Carol Wight (nom de plume, Petrarch), poem,
"Farewell."
Mr. Perkins is a senior at the Medical School
and was graduated with the degree of A. B.

No. 6

from Union College in 1893, and also from
Harvard in 1894. He is from Schenectady,
New York.
Mr. Wight is a member of the class of 19oo.
He is also from New York State, his home being in Brooklyn.
The report of the committee of judges which
follows explains itself:
JOHNS HOPKINS urrivieiterrv.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18, 1897.
Editors of News-Letter:
GENTLEMEN—We,your committee to judge
upon stories and poems submitted in competition for prizes offered by NEWS-LETTER, report:
1. No story submitted is deemed worthy of
prize offered.
2. The prize for poetical work is awarded to
the authors of "Voices of the Woods,"
and "Farewell." The prize is to be divided equally.
All of which is respectfully submitted.
H. B. ADAMS (Chairman),
HERBERT E. GREENE,
GUY CARLETON LEE.

VOICES OF THE WOODS.

As I wander to and fro,
Through the wood-paths, in and out,
In the air I seem to hear
Fairy voices round about—
Singing praises far and near
To Elizabeth.
All the flowers seem to say :
"Blest are we that we may lie
On her bosom, near her heart—
What care we that we must die,
So our lives some joy impart
To Elizabeth ?"

1

2

THE NEWS -LETTER.

Birds are singing in the trees,
As the branches swing and sway :
"Happy we that we can flee,
Whether near or far away,
To her presence, just to see
Fair Elizabeth.
Ah! ye lucky birds and flowers!
Would that I could take your place—
Could her meditations hear;
See the lights upon her face
When she thinks that no one's near.
Ah!Elizabeth.
Dost thou ever think of one
Who would always happy be
To fulfill thy lightest thought—
Dost thou ever think of me?
Love like mine cannot be bought,
Dear Elizabeth.

Ah,vanishing vision! and wilt thou cast
One smile on the heart whose heaven ends
When thou and beauty have southward past
To light the life of some happier friends?
When the ivory brow of morning glow
With crimson fire and the planets pale;
When the wind-wooed branches murmur low
Or roar as they wrest with the riing gale;
Iv.
When her icy kiss the darkness seal
On the rose-leaf lips of the dying day;
When the purple splendor of twilight steal
The heart from self and the world away;
Then, Oh!then, think, if thou wilt, that he,
Who well might mourn that we ever met,
Must dream on a love that can never be
Fulfilled, or else, if thou wilt, forget!

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
PROF. SHERWOOD ON "BERLIN."

Professor Sherwood delivered an address
before the Historical and Political Science Association on Friday evening. "Berlin" was
the subject he discussed, and his talk was based
Upon reminiscences of a short stop in that city
last summer. Professor Sherwood expressed
his disappointment with the famous boulevard,
Unter den Linden. It is true, the street is
about two hundred feet wide, and has its sides
adorned with rows of horse-chestnut trees and
lindens, though the latter are of rather a languishing nature.
In spite of several old ruins and crumbling
castles of historic interest, Berlin impresses
one as being a modern city. The houses are
built of brick and stone, and are almost entirely of a modern origin. The municipal government of Berlin is the pride of its inhabitants, and with much justice,for it is one of the
best governed cities in the world. In fact, the
officials seem to carry their measures for cleanliness, etc., almost to an extreme. During the
six weeks in which Professor Sherwood stayed
in the city it rained nearly every day; still the
galas between were busily occupied by the
water sprinklers.
One of the most serious problems which

3

confront the young men of the city is how to
make their moustaches grow in a way they
"hadn't orter." Hours are spent by the young
gallants of the city in barber shops, where tedious efforts are made to force the ends of the
moustaches to take that much-desired upward
movement. Although Berlin is one of the
largest cities in Europe, yet it does not give
one the impression of being a metropolis; especially is this fact brought out by the nature of
the newspapers, which are distinctly provincial
in character. Berlin is a great business centre,
but appearances are deceptive. Almost the
only signs of vigorous activity in the business
world are shown by the cabmen, who seem to
be possessed of a mania to run down and ride
over everything in sight. Professor Sherwood
found that it was not worth one's life to criticise the Emperor, though a considerable
amount of caution was usually employed in exercising that right.
The universities of Berlin have long been
famous, and students from all lands may be
found within their halls.
CAPITAL PUNISHI1ENT.

Statistics and Bible quotations were the favorite weapons of the speakers on the question
whether capital punishment should be abolished, which was discussed in the last session of
the Senate. The affirmative side won the debate. Those who took part, for the affirmative,
were Senators Dohme, Hubner and Hodges.
Those on the negative side were Senators Robinson, F. Smith and Brent. Senators Ballard
and Pender, who took part in the open debate,
showed that both these methods of argument
can be used to prove either yea or nay, and
that with them but little can be accomplished.
A short, humane plea, put forth by Senator
R. D. Miller, turned the tables against the adherents of rapid methods. The whole house
showed great interest in the progress and result of the debate.
The Senate will meet again on January 12,
1898, when Senators Gordon, Francis and Peters will speak for the annexation of Hawaii.
Senators M. Smith, Clunet and J. H. Palmer
will take the negative.

very weak.

PHYSICAL TRAININO,

The new gymnasium and cage are almost
completed, and in a short time presumably
they will be thrown open to the students. This
should give a new impulse to all branches of
athletics. Candidates for the teams will devote themselves to practice. Many will moralize about the value of systematic exercise, and
will begin to use the apparatus diligently. The
novelty will speedily wear off, the work will
become irksome and they will give it up. Interest will fail, and we may find ourselves, with
a new gymnasium and the largest cage in the
country in just the same position in regard to
athletics as before. We are confident, however,that this will not be so, for we believe that
the businesslike management that marks the
University in other departments will prevail
likewise in the gymnasium. Last year physical culture, as a part of the course, existed
chiefly on the class books. Those of us who
remember our frequent dashes in scanty apparel between the barnlike gymnasium and inadequate bathroom on the ground floor, and
our lockers close under the roof of an adjoin-

HAZING AT W. C. B.

We learn from reliable sources that the
sophomores of the Woman's College have actually been reprimanded for hazing the freshmen. It must be explained, however, that it is
not the rough-and-tumble, pot-social variety
with which we are familiar. At one time, we
are told, they presented the freshmen with
sticks of candy tied with green ribbons. Again
they mingled the bray of horns with the sweet
strains of freshmen concerts, and cut the jaunty
tassels from freshmen caps. We are surprised
and pained. After the Dean has persuaded
us to give up matriculation hazing, and the
freshmen and juniors have lived in peace for
three months, it is "perfectly awful" for them
to set us such an example.

of the "Ladies" College have formed a hockey
club. It's the same old thing—"Girls will be
boys." They are to be quite coy in their ar-

If they are wise, they will begin practice in the

shinny.

PRACTICAL ECONOMICS.

A professor in economics at the Hopkins
has aroused the admiration of the department
by his complete mastery of his subject. He
rode a wheel through Europe last summer,and
at the end of his trip sold it for more than he
paid for it. The professor is to be congratulated for his clever application of economic
theory to fact.

number of critical works on Old Testament literature and has paid special attention to the
Book of Psalms. He will lecture in McCoy
Hall, alternating with Mr. Burton, on ''Phases
of Jewish Religious Life After the Exile."
THE GLEE CLUB.

The Glee Club has been chosen, subject to
change, by Mr. P. S. Evans of the Medical
School, a graduate of Yale, who led the Club so
successfully last year. This year the personnel
is: First tenor—W. W. Francis, F. J. Clunet,
H. A. Fowler, C. P. Rogers, E. H. Hume. Second tenor—S. P. Harwood, H. M. Reese, C. S.
Hodges, J. P. Hill, G. C. Robinson. First
bass—W. P. Stewart, E. A. Robinson, Jr., L.
M. Warfield, J. G. Peters. Second bass—J. F.
Young, F. W. Smith, J. E Ewell, K. Jungbluth.
These men are to train, and only those
deemed proficient after training will be members of the Club.

LECTURES IN JANUARY.

Of the two gentlemen who will lecture early
in January, Mr. Richard Burton, the Donovan
lecturer, is interesting as a former student of
the University. He received his A. B. degree
from Trinity College, Connecticut, in 1883,
and was made a doctor of philosophy by Hopkins in 1888. In 1887 he won a literary prize of
$100. From here he went to his home (Hartford, Conn.)and became an editor of The Hartford Courant, one of the prominent newspapers
of the country.
Mr. Burton has the somewhat unusual distinction of being known as a poet and a newspaper man. He read an original poem at the
first commencement held in McCoy Hall, in
June, 1894. In a list of representative alumni
the '97 Hullabaloo contains a picture of Mr.
Burton with the subjects of his theses. He will
deliver six lectures in McCoy Hall on "The
Modern Novel."

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Mr. J. B. McCallum of the second-year class
met with a painful accident on Sunday, December 5, which, however, luckily did not result seriously. While walking down the street
two dogs that were tied together ran up to him,
one on each side. They tripped him up, and
his head struck on the sidewalk, lacerating his
scalp and knocking him senseless for some little time. As a result he was laid up for a number of days.
Dr. S. F. Baker was confined to his apartments last week with a cold and an attack of
tonsilitis. Dr. C. F. Barden had charge of his
class during his absence.
Professor Brooks' lectures proved very attractive to the medical students and the faculty
of the Medical School, many of them having
attended all the lectures, and a still larger number most of them.

ATHLETICS.
HOCKEY.

The affairs of the Hockey League have been
settled and the opposition to the Maryland
Hockey Club has won its point debarring that
team from the League and getting ten per cent.
of the gate receipts at all games. The 'Varsity team played its first game on last Tuesday
night week, and lost to Northampton by 4
goals to 2. Scholl did not play at goal, and his
work in the field was not comparable with his
unexcelled goal tending. The 'Varsity was
outplayed in team work, the Northampton
men putting up a rattling, strong game.
Indoor baseball will begin as soon as the
cage is completed. The different classes have
been requested to organize teams to compete
for a prize, which will be presented to the
winning team. The prize is to be a handsome
banner, on which will appear the names of the
victorious players. The schedule of games will
be arranged later on.
On Monday some of the gymnasium apparatus was put in place. Several additions have
been made, among which are a double rowing
machine and striking- bag drum. A very fine
wrestling carpet has also been procured. This
carpet has long been needed. It is probable
that Professor Doyle will give lessons in
wrestling two afternoons a week.
The floor of the cage will be leveled and
rolled during the Christmas recess, and the
foundation for the running track will be laid.
The track will have to be banked somewhat
at the corners of the cage.
